title: Quiz 4: Medicine FQE June 2022
description: Final Qualifying Examination from June 2022 covering Clinical Medicine and Surgery.

questions.question: A 60-year-old male with a history of colon malignancy and recent DVT treatment reports sudden right-sided chest pain and difficulty breathing. What is the most likely diagnosis?

richContent.content:
Clinical Scenario

History: Colon Malignancy, recent DVT.
Symptoms: Sudden chest pain, Dyspnea.

options.text: Could â€“ disease (Typo in source, irrelevant)

questions.explanation: Malignancy and recent DVT are major risk factors for Pulmonary Embolism (PE). Sudden onset chest pain and dyspnea are hallmark symptoms.
questions.hint: The clot moved from the leg to the lungs.

questions.question: What is the immediate help to give a patient suffering from a snake bite (suspected black mamba) before reaching the hospital?

options.text: Place a stone and tie around the bite site
Apply a tourniquet above bite and one below the bite site
Slightly slice the bite area and suck out the poison
Just reassure and immobilize the patient as you seek for help

questions.explanation: Standard first aid involves immobilization (to slow venom spread via lymphatics) and reassurance. Tourniquets, cutting, and sucking are contraindicated.
questions.hint: Do NOT cut or tie. Keep them still.

questions.question: A patient is coughing out blood and presents with sweating, dizziness, cold extremities, and distant heartbeat. Which statement is true?

options.text: Give a lot of raw eggs to remove the poison

questions.explanation: The signs (sweating, dizziness, cold extremities, weak heart sounds) indicate uncompensated Hypovolemic Shock due to blood loss (Haemoptysis).

questions.question: Which of the following is a MEDICAL cause of a space-occupying lesion?

options.text: A patient who fell from height
A HIV positive patient with cerebral toxoplasmosis
A motorbike rider involved in head on collision
A child hit on the head while playing

questions.explanation: Cerebral Toxoplasmosis is an infectious (medical) cause of brain lesions. The other options describe trauma leading to hematomas (surgical/traumatic causes).
questions.hint: Look for the infection, not the injury.

questions.question: A patient has lost the left nasolabial fold, cannot close her left eye, and her tongue deviates to the right. Which statement is true?

options.text: That's a typical presentation of facial palsy
Prescribe face emollients and advise her to stay away from sunlight

questions.explanation: Loss of nasolabial fold and inability to close the eye (lagophthalmos) are classic signs of Facial Nerve (CN VII) palsy.

questions.question: What is the best action to take when someone starts having seizures?

options.text: Offer warm coffee or oral glucose
Call for ambulance without delay (if first seizure/prolonged)
Let them be on a soft surface and pillow under the head

questions.explanation: Protect the patient from injury (cushion head, soft surface). Do not restrain or put anything in the mouth.
questions.hint: Protect the head, do not restrain.

questions.question: Which investigation is crucial in a patient who has had a convulsive episode in a tropical setting?
questions.explanation: Cerebral Malaria is a common cause of convulsions in endemic areas. A BS for MPS is mandatory.
questions.hint: Rule out the commonest tropical parasite.

questions.question: Which statement is true regarding Rheumatoid Arthritis?

options.text: Nowadays there is cure for mild disease
Lifelong disease modifying drugs are prescribed

questions.explanation: RA requires lifelong management with Disease-Modifying Antirheumatic Drugs (DMARDs) like Methotrexate to prevent joint destruction.

questions.question: A 30-year-old male presents with greenish urethral discharge and dysuria. What is the best management?

options.text: Give meloxicam as is a good analgesic and see him after 2 days
Single intramuscular injection of ceftriaxone is used for treatment
Reassure him and advise to take a lot of fluids

questions.explanation: Greenish discharge suggests Gonorrhea. Standard treatment is IM Ceftriaxone (plus Azithromycin/Doxycycline for Chlamydia coverage).

questions.question: Which key message regarding Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs) is true?

options.text: Condom use is recommended only when the sexual partner has signs of infection
All patients treated for STIs should be tested for HIV
Sharing of drugs with spouses is ok
All STIs are symptomatic on day 2

questions.explanation: Provider Initiated Testing and Counseling (PITC) for HIV is standard for all STI patients due to shared risk factors.
questions.hint: Always check for the 'big one' when treating STIs.

questions.question: What is the correct definition of 'Opportunistic Infections' in HIV/AIDS?

options.text: Infections that must occur in HIV patients
Infections taking advantages of reduced immunity

questions.explanation: OIs exploit the weakened immune system to cause disease that would not normally occur in a healthy host.
questions.hint: They seize the 'opportunity' of low immunity.

questions.question: A patient presents with skin ulcers. Which of the following conditions is NOT part of the differential diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Vitiligo causes depigmentation (white patches) but the skin remains intact; it does not ulcerate. Cancers and SJS cause breakdown/ulceration.
questions.hint: Which one only changes color but doesn't break the skin?

questions.question: For a child with Tungiasis (Jiggers), which action best describes management?

options.text: Application of Vaseline suffocates and kills the parasite
Link with public health officer only

questions.explanation: Standard treatment involves suffocating the flea with petroleum jelly (Vaseline) or dimethicone, allowing for easier removal or death of the parasite.

questions.question: Which condition presents with raised, shiny, scaly lesions on extensor regions?
questions.explanation: Psoriasis plaques are typically erythematous with silvery scales and favor extensor surfaces (knees, elbows).

questions.question: Which statement is true regarding Leishmaniasis?

options.text: Treatment is by injection of sodium stibogluconate
Reduviid bug is a known vector

questions.explanation: Sodium Stibogluconate (SSG) is the standard treatment for Visceral Leishmaniasis (Kala-azar).

questions.question: Identify the soil-transmitted helminth that is a common cause of anaemia and eosinophilia:
questions.explanation: Hookworms (Ancylostoma) suck blood from the intestine, causing iron deficiency anemia and eosinophilia.

questions.question: A child presents with scalp hair loss, well-demarcated ring lesions, and excoriation marks. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Tinea capitis is the medical term for fungal infection (ringworm) of the scalp.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT typically associated with haemoptysis?
questions.explanation: Asthma causes dry cough and wheezing. Haemoptysis is rare/unassociated. TB, Cancer, and Bronchiectasis are major causes of coughing blood.
questions.hint: Which one involves airway spasm rather than tissue destruction?

questions.question: Which condition presents with cough, chest tightness, and dyspnoea due to chronic airway inflammation affecting flow?
questions.explanation: The definition fits Asthma: chronic inflammation causing reversible obstruction and the classic triad of symptoms.

questions.question: Which statement is NOT true regarding management of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)?

options.text: Stable patients can be managed at home
Infections are associated with acute exacerbation
Bronchodilators and oral corticosteroids are not recommended
Cyanosis and edema may influence prognosis

questions.explanation: This statement is FALSE (therefore the correct answer). Bronchodilators and Steroids ARE the core treatment for COPD.
questions.hint: Find the false statement about treatment.

questions.question: Describe the chest pain located centrally, radiating to jaw/left arm, dull/constricting, precipitated by exertion and relieved by rest:
questions.explanation: This is the textbook description of Stable Angina Pectoris (Ischemic heart pain).

questions.question: Which drug class is a cornerstone in the treatment of heart failure?
questions.explanation: ACE Inhibitors reduce afterload and remodeling, improving survival in Heart Failure.

questions.question: Which statement is true regarding a survivor of cardiac arrest due to exercise-induced ischemia?

options.text: Patients are not at risk of another episode
Prognosis is similar to uncomplicated ischemia
Are advised to undergo implantable cardiac defibrillators (ICD)

questions.explanation: Survivors of cardiac arrest are at high risk of recurrence and typically require an ICD for secondary prevention.
questions.hint: They need a device to shock the heart if it happens again.

questions.question: What is Cardiac Tamponade?

options.text: Accumulation of blood/fluid in pericardial space compressing the heart

questions.explanation: Tamponade is the compression of the heart by fluid in the pericardial sac, preventing filling.

questions.question: Which of the following drugs is generally NOT recommended or least preferred for stable angina due to reflex tachycardia (unless modified release)?
questions.explanation: Short-acting Nifedipine causes rapid vasodilation and reflex tachycardia, which can worsen ischemia. Amlodipine/Verapamil/Beta-blockers are preferred.

questions.question: A 21-year-old male presents with painless bilateral cervical lymph node enlargement, fever, and night sweats. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Painless lymphadenopathy + B Symptoms (Fever/Night Sweats) in a young adult is classic Hodgkin's Lymphoma.

questions.question: Bence Jones proteins are found in the urine in which condition?
questions.explanation: Bence Jones proteins (light chains) are a diagnostic marker for Multiple Myeloma.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a symptom of hypothyroidism?
questions.explanation: Hypothyroidism causes hair loss (alopecia) and brittle hair, not overgrowth. The other symptoms are typical.
questions.hint: Think about metabolism slowing down - hair usually falls out.

questions.question: A patient presents with 6 days of lower abdominal pain, dysuria, high grade fever, and loin-angle tenderness. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Fever + Dysuria + Loin Tenderness indicates the infection has ascended to the kidneys (Pyelonephritis).

questions.question: Which statement is true regarding Barrett's Oesophagus?

options.text: Squamous lining is replaced by keratinized epithelium
Is as a result of chronic gastro oesophageal reflux disease
Diagnosis is made with chest X-ray

questions.explanation: Barrett's is a metaplastic change (Squamous to Columnar) caused by chronic acid reflux (GERD). It is pre-malignant.

questions.question: Which statement is correct regarding Peptic Ulcer Disease treatment?

options.text: Treats H. Pylori with PPI + two antibiotics for 7-14 days
Alcohol is the single most known aggravating factor
Common cause of dyspepsia in pre-school children

questions.explanation: Triple therapy (PPI + Clarithromycin + Amoxicillin/Metronidazole) is the standard eradication regimen.

questions.question: Which strategy is most useful in curbing the spread of a Vibrio cholera outbreak?

options.text: Patients encouraged to receive treatment in their locality (CTC)

questions.explanation: Treating patients locally in Cholera Treatment Centers (CTCs) prevents the movement of infectious individuals and curbs spread.
questions.hint: Don't move the patient, move the treatment.

questions.question: A 25-year-old male presents with severe periumbilical pain radiating to the back after an alcohol binge. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Alcohol binge + Severe pain radiating to back = Acute Pancreatitis.

questions.question: Which of the following predisposes a person to colon cancer?
questions.explanation: Radiation therapy to the abdomen increases the risk of subsequent malignancies. Fiber and antioxidants are protective.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a component of a Full Blood Count (FBC/CBC) report?
questions.explanation: Serum Iron is a biochemistry test, not part of the standard hematology Full Blood Count.
questions.hint: CBC measures cells, not chemistry levels.

questions.question: Which finding is ABNORMAL in a peripheral blood film?
questions.explanation: Blasts (immature cells) should NEVER be in peripheral blood in a healthy person. Even a low count is abnormal.
questions.hint: Immature cells shouldn't be in the blood.

questions.question: A 13-year-old with haemophilia needs education. Which complication is important to mention?

options.text: Factors VIII concentrate can only be administered in a referral hospital
Factor VIII does not carry disease risk
One complication of this disease is compartment syndrome
Factors VIII cannot be administered prophylactically

questions.explanation: Bleeding into muscles (hematomas) can increase pressure causing compartment syndrome.

questions.question: What is the implication for a patient with a Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) of 14 ml/min?

options.text: Is a candidate for dialysis and transplant

questions.explanation: GFR < 15 ml/min indicates End Stage Renal Disease (Stage 5 CKD), requiring renal replacement therapy.

questions.question: Which imaging modality is best for investigating dilatation of collecting renal systems (Hydronephrosis)?
questions.explanation: Renal Ultrasound is the non-invasive gold standard for detecting obstruction/dilation.

questions.question: What is a common presentation of Diabetes Mellitus?
questions.explanation: Polyphagia, Polyuria, and Polydipsia are the 3 Ps of Diabetes.

questions.question: Arrange the steps for managing Organophosphate Poisoning:
questions.explanation: ABC first, prevent absorption, atropinize to save life, then antidote.

questions.question: Select 5 factors that aggravate Gouty attacks:
questions.explanation: Purines, Alcohol, Dehydration, and certain drugs (Thiazides) increase uric acid.

questions.question: Arrange the first 4 links in the Out-of-Hospital Chain of Survival:

items.text: Early Recognition and Call for Help

questions.explanation: Call -> CPR -> Shock -> Medics.

questions.question: Select common signs and symptoms of Heart Failure:
questions.explanation: Fluid overload signs (Edema, JVP, Crackles) and pump failure symptoms (Dyspnea, Fatigue).

questions.question: Select diagnostic tests for TB and target groups for Isoniazid Prophylaxis (IPT):
questions.explanation: Tests: Sputum/CXR. IPT targets: Under 5 contacts and HIV+ patients.

questions.question: Select common causes of Gastritis:
questions.explanation: H. pylori, Drugs (NSAIDs), and Lifestyle (Alcohol/Smoking) are key.

questions.question: Select routine practices for reviewing Diabetes patients:
questions.explanation: Regular review involves checking control (Sugar/BP/Weight), complications (Feet/Eyes), and lifestyle.
questions.hint: Check the sugar, check the feet.

questions.question: Select preventive measures for Hepatitis B:

options.text: Safe Sharps Handling / No Needle Sharing

questions.explanation: Hep B is blood/fluid borne. Vaccine and avoiding fluid contact are key. (Boiling water is for Hep A/E).

questions.question: Case: 28-year-old female found comatose on the road. Select appropriate management steps:

richContent.content:
Clinical Case

Found unconscious. Vitals stable. Unresponsive.

Possible Causes: Trauma, Alcohol/Drugs, Hypoglycemia.

questions.explanation: Coma cocktail approach: ABCs, check sugar (treat if low), fluids, position to prevent aspiration. CT scan before LP.
